course.subject: ELEC
course.name: Advanced Topics in Nanoelectronics
course.description: Introduction to state-of-the-art development in the broad area of nanoelectronics, including concepts and devices for spin electronics and quantum information science. Students are expected to demonstrate the capability of applying fundamental principles to understand advanced electronic devices through hands-on homework projects.

reviews.author: Fpn
reviews.comment_content:
In this course, we study two important topics: (1) magnetic materials and devices, (2) quantum information algorithms, devices, and systems.

For topic (1), we learn about the application of magnetic materials and devices, what is magnetism, typical magnetic materials, magneto-electrical and magneto-optical properties, magnetic memory and beyond.

For topic (2), it will emphasize on application of quantum information technology, examples of quantum algorithms, quantum devices (superconducting qubits), and quantum systems.

The lecture schedule roughly looks like this:

Topic 1: introduction to spin electronics and quantum information technology
Topic 2: magnetism and magnetic materials
Topic 3: magneto-electrical and magneto-optical properties
Topic 4: magneto-resistive random-access memory and beyond
Topic 5: basics for quantum information technology
Topic 6: quantum circuits and algorithms
Topic 7: physical realization of qubit
Topic 8: circuit quantum electrodynamics and qubit readout
Topic 9: qubit manipulation and dynamics
Topic 10: quantum error correction
reviews.comment_teaching: Excellent powerpoint slides, but some points are not written so you need to take notes too. Prof also gives regular in-class polling to make sure we can catch up with the materials. He also allocates weekly office hours for students to ask.
reviews.comment_grading:
- Attendance: 1 pt for each class (counted by in-class polling)
- Weekly hands-on homework: 10 pts maximum for each one*
- Peer review report: 1 pt for each review report.*
- Midterm spintronics project (25 pt)
- Final quantum information science project (25 pt)
- Oral presentation, choose either midterm or final (10 pt)

* most students did it once, can be more.

Prof claimed as long as we reached total of 50+ points, we will get A range.
reviews.comment_workload:
This course has one three-hour lecture every week, just like other PG courses.

The workload is not that hard, since we can choose any topics we want for the projects as long as they are related to spintronics or quantum computing.
